utterances: As people in Madaya and Aleppo and Homs and all over Syria try to get through their days, the diplomatic process is in pieces.
Of all the solutions proposed, it seems the one thing everyone agrees on is there are no good ones.
Aaron David Miller is a vice president at the Woodrow Wilson Center for Scholars.
He served as an adviser to secretaries of state of both Republican and Democratic administrations.
Aaron, thanks very much for being back with us.
A pleasure to be here.
Did Russia use those talks between Russia and the U.S.
- did the Assad regime use them to buy time while they destroyed Aleppo and other areas?

I mean, now in hindsight, I don't think there's any doubt that Putin used phony cease-fire talks as a sort of clever way to allow Moscow to keep one hand in diplomacy and to calibrate it but also to keep its feet on the Syrian battlefield in defense of Assad.
Is it worthwhile to make another attempt to talk to Russia?
You know, I think Mr. Putin is most comfortable, frankly, when he has a diplomatic process going and a military process on the ground.
He fashions himself not simply a combatant but a broker and a mediator and a great power.
It is high time that the United States remove right now this sort of Potemkin Village fraud in which Mr. Putin seems to have the best of both worlds.

Pull it away, keep the focus on Vladimir Putin as aggressor, tar him with the responsibility and the Assads for the humanitarian catastrophe and don't give him the legitimacy to argue that in fact he can play both on the battlefield and in the diplomatic corridors of Geneva and New York.
There have been reports again that the administration's considering applying more U.S.
military power in the region.
How do you feel about that?
You know, I think it's late for the U.S.
to intercede, and I think this administration largely in response to its predecessor has clearly determined that it needs to be very cautious and risk averse on Syria.
You could implement any number of what I would argue are half measures - no-fly zones, demilitarized area safe zones, humanitarian corridors.
You could supply more sophisticated weapons to the rebels.
You could attack Assad directly.
And I think the one question I would ask is Putin, Assad, the Iranians, Hezbollah, are prepared to die in defense of their national interests in Syria.
And the question, really, Scott, is are we?

If in fact Congress is willing to empower the president, the American public is prepared for a major investment in another Middle Eastern war in the wake of Iraq and Afghanistan, then sure, make Syria a major priority - perhaps the priority.
But it's not just the day-after problem for the United States in Syria.
It's the decade-after problem.
At the same time, isn't there a cost, even a lot of cost, for doing nothing?
I think that Obama will be judged very harshly as a consequence of his failure to do more.
So yes, there is a cost, but I would argue to you that with respect to humanitarian interventions, this is not just a Barack Obama problem.

From the Nazi Holocaust to Cambodia to Rwanda to Darfur to Congo, the United States simply does not have, for any number of reasons, a consistent or terribly uplifting record in terms of interceding in conflicts which involve mass slaughter and mass killing.
It is a Republican problem, it's a Democratic problem, and it's an American problem.
Aaron David Miller, vice president at the Woodrow Wilson Center for Scholars and the author most recently of ""The End of Greatness."" Thanks so much for being with us.
Thank you, Scott.
When you call for an ambulance, you might expect the crew to take you to the nearest hospital.
But sometimes the closest emergency department just isn't taking new patients.
Several hospitals in Cleveland have come together to try to keep ERs open for all the patients' ambulances so they can bring them in.
WCPN's Sarah Jane Tribble reports.
It is a run-of-the-mill call for east Cleveland's EMS squad.
They're going to treat a man with a severe nosebleed.
One-four-five's enroute, part two.
Anthony Savoy is the head medic.
(Unintelligible).
The patient walks woozily out to the ambulance.
Savoy calls ahead to University Hospitals.
It's the closest emergency department, and he wants to make sure they have room to take the patient.
They get in that day, but it wasn't a given.
For years, it's been common practice for UH to go on diversion.
That means when he calls the hospital, UH says they don't have the room or the staff to handle the patient.
The team then has to drive to another hospital, often the Cleveland Clinic, about a mile away.
If we get diverted and then we get a call while we're at the hospital, our response time will be lengthened by maybe a minute, maybe two minutes.
That may not seem like much time, but a minute or two is critical for some patients, says Dr. James Feldman, an emergency medicine doctor in Boston.
We have strong evidence that people who have critical illness or injury who have a delayed time to treatment do worse.
A study released earlier this year found that heart attack patients whose ambulances were diverted from crowded emergency rooms to hospitals farther away were more likely to be dead a year later.
In Cleveland this year, UH temporarily closed its main campus emergency room to certain patients for more than 550 hours.
Another large hospital system, MetroHealth, clocked more than 400 diversion hours.
Jane Dus, chief nursing officer at University Hospitals, says an aging population and hospital closures have increased demand on emergency departments.
We've seen a 56 percent increase in our squad volume over five years, so we're getting many more squads coming to us.
Dus recently joined Cleveland area hospitals in negotiating an agreement to stop going on diversion.
Indeed, all four major health systems in Cleveland say they will accept all ambulances starting February 15 in 2016.
If the hospitals are successful, the region will join a select few that have tackled the issue.
After years of effort, the Seattle area has stopped nearly all diversions.
Boston's Dr. Feldman says Massachusetts passed relations in 2009 to ban ambulance diversions after voluntary attempts failed.
Hospitals there had to re-evaluate operations, in some cases, encouraging elective surgeries to be done closer to the weekends to free up beds on other floors throughout the week.
Video of a young man running away unarmed being shot three times in the back.
It should be open and closed.
And the fact that it's not is super problematic.
Since the jurors live 200 miles away, the trial will run through the week and into the weekend if necessary.
For NPR News, I'm An-Li Herring in Pittsburgh.
Let's continue now with presidential politics.
This week, both candidates had reason to ask that age-old question, with friends like these, dot, dot, dot.
For Obama, the friend in question was the Reverend Jesse Jackson.
For McCain, it was former Texas senator and now former economics adviser, Phil Gramm.
Joining us now is our friend, always, NPR news analyst, Juan Williams.
Hi, Juan.
Hi, my old friend.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Not so old!
Who're you calling old?
Hey, my young friend.
(Soundbite of laughter)
OK.
Well, by now, everyone knows the gist of what Jesse Jackson said on Fox.
And I'm just wondering, is Reverend Jesse Jackson, is he speaking for an older generation of African-American leaders?'
I think he is, Madeleine, but he's now also speaking for himself.

I think he's got a great concern about being pushed offstage by a new kind of political leadership that's speaking on pragmatic terms about problems in black America and saying, we've got to fix the schools.
We've got to contend with this dropout rate.
And Barack Obama, on Fathers' Day, spoke at a black church in Chicago and said, black fathers have to do a better of job of being responsible parents.

He also said, in some cases, maybe the government should be funding churches, as part of the - President Bush's faith-based initiative, to deliver social services, revealing, in a sense, that Barack Obama was talking about black people taking personal responsibility, not playing into the victim mindset, and saying the government should be doing this, or white people responsible for our plight, but here are steps you can take to help yourself.
And I think Jackson felt that's not the message that a prominent black leader should be delivering.

In an earlier occasion, now, during this campaign cycle, by the way, when there was protest down in Louisiana against the treatment of some black high-school students, Barack Obama said, we let the justice system work.
Jesse Jackson's response was, he's acting white.
So, again, I think you see that generational divide come into play, and should Barack Obama be elected president, you can expect to see more of it.
Well, politically, does Obama come out looking better because of it?
You know, it's interesting, because as a matter of political strategy right now, Barack Obama has, you know, has been moving to the center.

He is after Independent, white voters, especially some suburbanites and especially woman, and for them to say, oh, wait a second, he is at a distance from Jesse Jackson, these are not the same people, that can only help Barack Obama.
Maybe a real friend, then, in a Jesse Jackson..
Well, it's right.
Maybe not intentionally, but in fact, a friend.
OK.
So let's turn to John McCain.

He also has a problem with Texas senator, former Texas senator, Phil Gramm, who made some interesting remarks about Americans who are complaining about the current state of things in the economy, basically saying, we are a nation of whiners.
McCain came up forcefully saying he didn't agree with that.

Big problem for John McCain here, Madeleine, because when you get former Senator Gramm, who, you know, is a PhD in economics, saying most Americans are suffering what he called a mental recession, and are whining and complaining for no reason, look at the unemployment rate, look at Wall Street, look at profits, what are they complaining about?

He really contradicted what McCain is trying to deliver as now the core message of his campaign, which is that we are in touch with the economic anxiety in the country, and Republicans are going to take action to help you with kitchen-table issues.
That's why McCain was quick to say, Phil Gramm doesn't speak for me.
In addition, Madeleine, he also said maybe he would appoint former Senator Graham as ambassador to Belarus.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But then he said maybe the people there wouldn't want to him.
Juan, your best political conversation of the week?
You know, Madeleine, this is an interesting one.
This week, if you remember, President Bush won on FISA legislation that gave immunity to the telecom companies.
And in discussions on Capitol Hill this week, there were people who were asking me, do you think that Bush ever stops and thinks that he has one every major fight when it comes to this terror issue?
Obama voted for this legislation.
Even a Democratically controlled Congress fears President Bush and refuses to challenge him on civil-liberties issue.
This is the start of a conversation we're going to have more of as we get towards the end of the Bush term.
Exactly what did the Bush presidency mean?
Thank you very much.
